er_text: Party of five Went in on a Saturday mid day Food is good portions are large Had 2 American burgers pasta and a Greek salad. New York cheese cake for desert107dollars including tip Service is excellent and friendly We will be back

Food was on pointe. Coffee was standard. Service was quick and attentive. A total local dive with lots of character. Ate a spinach and feta omelette and it was delicious! Hubby had the French toast--also a hit. Looking for a local joint? This hits the mark!

This restaurant is by far the best restaurant I have been to in New York! The staff is friendly and very attentive! The food is amazing and is made In a timely fashion and not to mention very affordable. It's in walking distance of the met, Central Park and many other sites. I 10/10 would recommend this place!!
LOVE this place! Very quiet and friendly. A little pricey but it's NYC. Huge portion sizes! Wait staff were the friendliest people I've met in the city. 10/10 would come back!

We come by every time we go to the Met. They always greet and sit you down right away, and most everyone that walks in is known by name. Look in the kitchen, the cooks are back there smiling and talking while they work. Hard to not like a friendly place with good food.
A great little Greek-owned diner in Manhattan. Very friendly, delicious breakfasts, and a good deal for Manhattan. The corned beef hash and eggs is particularly good, as is the eggs benedict.

There is a point where something common like a glass of orange juice is so extraordinarily expensive that I think the waiter should warn the patron.  An $8.70 large OJ is extreme even at the highest end place, and this place isn't high end.  The food was decent, just being your own juice.

If you are looking to pay $21 for dry, chewy blueberry pancakes and bacon (tax and tip included), this is the place to go. FYI, don't let the flirtatious waiters fool you - they overcharged us for our meal, applying tax twice. I have a suspicion the owner does this because his business is failing.
Needed a deli near the Met. Asked a NYC sanitation worker where to eat and he recommended this! Very intimate real N.Y. feel  Regular diner food, tasty and quick. Wait staff were superb.
Hands down the best chicken salad ever!  Great service.  Excellent location.  Outstanding menu.  We will definitely eat there more often now that we've found it!
Flew in from the west coast and staying nearby. Hands down the best service I've witness in NYC. Everyone else has been so pushy about thing and these guys are quick and kind about it.
old school diner, attentive, friendly waitstaff, food is delicious. cant go wrong here. booths or sit at the counter, decent music too

Excellent food and amazing service.  This local diner is a neighborhood institution, where I can go early morning, sit down at the counter,  grab a donut and a coffee..or a nice stack of pancakes, eggs and bacon.  I love the crew who works here and they're always smiling and cracking jokes to make ya laugh.  They're a lotta places around the neighborhood but none of them have the atmosphere, comfort and charm of the New Amity.

I stumbled upon this classic old school diner on my way up Madison Avenue one night as I was looking for anyplace to eat. I wasn't disappointed: I got a gyro with no mayo. It hit the spot. The staff were helpful and friendly. The waiter must have run out to deliver leftover bags and scarves to leaving customers about four times. I admired his kindness on a cold night.

I wanted a restaurant experience where I could take off my beanie in the peace of knowing it would be safe should I be so absentminded as to forget it. This was not the restaurant experience I was looking for.
Delicious and truly local. Owner and servers know their regulars. Charming old diner feel and great friendly (and quick) service.
A classic old-school NY diner! Great, friendly, warm service. Filled with lots of regular customers.

This place is absolutely amazing! It was an unplanned stop but we are so happy that we found this hidden gem. The food is incredible, the atmosphere is so comfortable, and the staff are some of the nicest and most personable people we've ever met. Hands down, one of the best places we've come across during our vacation trip.
The blue beanie was in the back, chained to the wall and cooking gyros while sobbing. Free him!
Great service, good food and variety. Came in on a rainy cold day, and it was a decent place to relax, warm up with coffee, and eat breakfast before heading to the museums.

Authentic greek food? Yeah right they can't even do an authentic gyro! No shawarma or greek yogurt? I even found hair in my gyro. The chips were bland af and the waiter had such a stuck up attitude whenever I asked for things. For the price the food sucked and the service sucked, there're better places in NYC for a good feed at this price point. AVOID.

Eh. So.Hmm....... How do I begin?  I can't say I really liked this place and I can't say I disliked it either.  It is located on the Upper East Side near the Metropolitan Museum and there are not a ton of dining options in the neighborhood.  What drew me in there was that it looked like an old school NYC place looks like.  Kind of a throwback to the 70s or earlier but very clean and super busy.  The place is small but I was seated right away and the service was quick.  Since the place is so small if you are sitting near the front you are likely to have people hovering over you while they wait for tables so if you don't like to be in close proximity go for the back of the room.  This is definitely a place for locals. The greeter called several of them by name as they came in so they must have a following in the area.  It took me a minute or two to realize that while the place is totally casual and many other folks were coming in wearing jeans and sweaters, that my jeans and sweater came Kohl's or Macys and these people were wearing Brooks Brothers and Burberry.  Par for the course in that neighborhood.  The biggest disappointment is the food for what you pay.  15.00 for a tuna melt is a bit steep.  Still since I was in NYC I knew that was not unusual.  But what I got was two pieces of toast served open face with a scoop of tuna on each and a melted slice of American cheese, a tiny spot of coleslaw and a pathetic pickle.  Head a few blocks east and find better food for the money.

If you're thinking about eating here, do yourself a favor... Don't. Take your hard earned money, go up the block and get a sandwich from dean n deluca. Or if you're short on cash grab a pile of greasey slop from the halal cart, because the quality of food in this "diner" is no better.

I stole Ethan's hat. He looked stupid in it so I took it: you should be thanking me for saving the creep from himself.The New Amity is a great New York experience. I was there two days ago with friends from Australia -- I wanted them to get a feel for an authentic ew York coffee shop.

Went here with my sister and caretaker, and I kid you not, their "gyros" had MAYONNAISE instead of yogurt and BREAKFAST SAUSAGE instead of shawarma.  Unbelievable.  Then our server was coughing all over our food and the entire restaurant, not even trying to cover his mouth.  Absolutely disgusting.  We were horrified.  This guy looked like he was stage 3 AIDs/bronchitis.  He was coughing on everything.  This was like biological terror, this guy should be locked up.Anyway, my sister's a total cookie monster so we bought a $3 cookie that was dipped in chocolate and we're thinking there's no way they can screw this up.  She took a bite and spit it out, and when I took a bite I realized I'm pretty sure they're using sand instead of flour.  And I think the chocolate may have been made of wax with a little brown food coloring, here ya go.My sister/caretaker walks me home after a good ol' fashioned chub 'n' tuck and we vape some phat clouds on the way there.  We get home and realize my blue beanie is missing.  I call the restaurant and the conversation went like this:Me: "Hey, do you guys have a blue hat?  I was just there."Him: "I don't know, we got blue hats, what do you want?"Me: "Well I was just there, can you look and see?"Him: "It's on the other side of the room, if somebody comes and gets it, they get it."Me: "WTF dude?!?! I'm a paying customer!!  I was just there!!"WTF, is this real life?Him: "Okay, okay, I'll go look for you.  It's a blue hat, it's a blue hat."Me: "Okay, can you hold it for me?"Him: "No, I don't know, if someone come, they get it, we put it to the front of the store."I'm gonna come tomorrow and I'm gonna leave with something.  You know what I mean?  I don't know if it's gonna be a hat, it might just be an omelette.  Dude freakin' jacked my hat.

I give this place a 4 star because I like the staff, I love listening to the regulars that come in and banter with the staff. The food is served quickly and hot. Your coffee cup and water glass is always full. Portions are decent size. What more can you ask for from an American diner. I have only gone for breakfast (fan of the #2 Two eggs, choice of meat, homefries, toast, coffee). But I saw someone order the soup of the day, and it looked good. Going to try to go for lunch next time. I have seen people call in to get take out.

Stayed over a friend's house and she had to work in the morning so I wanted to get some breakfast somewhere. A local diner would be perfect. It had good Yelp reviews and I liked the vibe so I figured it'd be solid.However, I had to say I left pretty underwhelmed.First of all, the menu is pretty meh. Even by diner standards. I know it's NYC, but I felt like there just wasn't a lot going on there. A few pretty meh sounding omelettes. A few breakfast specials.The place is very affordable I'll say. I spent 10 bucks, but honestly, I would've spent more for a more interesting menu selection.I ordered two eggs, wheat toast, sausage, and home fries. It came out with bacon. Oops.So they made me the sausage and another few minutes later, I had my breakfast again. Except by now my toast isn't even close to hot. And the sausage was... yeah. Kinda gross.The home fries were also pretty bland. I had to add a bunch of salt.It was all pretty fast. And cheap. And the guys there seemed nice.But overall, I had a pretty meh experience. But if you want meh and you want it fast and cheap, this is your place!
give ethan's hat backpapa unbless

We were at the Met and starving for a place to eat a late lunch. I referred to YELP and found The New Amity Restaurant. It was a quick walk down some beautiful residential streets on the UES. There were four of us and they sat us in a booth. While the booth was a bit cramped, the seats were oh so comfortable!!  I could have sat there all afternoon! The service we had was spectacular, all due to our server Jesus! He made the restaurant for us! The food was awesome... good American food and not overly priced. We were all pleased with our selections. If you're looking for a classic NY diner, check it out!

I would like to back up a few fellows reviewers about that is an average diner, as traditional it can get, as old as the "dinosaur", there are really a few of them left in the neighborhood. However if you are just hungry, not looking for any delicacies / fine dinning, this place is it!Pasta in white clam source $16.00, tasted kinda bland, my 6 points of 10, but the servicing size made me speechless.Buffalo Wings $9.95, they looked simply fried chicken, and I mentioned that the buffalo wings shouldn't look like fired chicken, and they said this is the way they do it there!I believe I wasn't getting the actual Buffalo Wings, the kitchen made mistake!
Great place.  Good food.  Great staff!   Huge portions.  Close to the MET.   Try the chicken parm.

Don't go here. I wanted a simple grilled piece of chicken, waiter said "could not be done." I ordered cheese blinz and they were fried, small, and cost $15.00. Tea and coffee was ice cold. So not a New Yorker's diner. Don't go.
Nice place, great staff very fast service.The manager is extremely friendly, nice and gentle.The food is very tasty and the place is not huge but the seats are confortable and wide.

Really close to the MET and I was not completely appalled by the prices. My server was a little too sassy for my taste but the Turkey Cheeseburger totally floats my boat and the fries were crispy so I will count my experience with Amity as a positive one.Only three stars because I like my service without your bad day sprinkled on it, Sweetheart.

Mediocre diner food but FANTASTIC service. This place is awesome. The staff here is SUPER nice and seem to know all the locals and regulars by name (and nickname). They were so kind to us, even with our toddler, and made us feel like we were at home. If we lived in the area, we'd probably make this a regular place because the service is so good. The food is great, typical NYC diner food - nothing too spectacular but all the usual finds like tuna melts and 24 hour breakfast and terrible burnt coffee diner.  They will always make sure your coffee and water cup are full. Although this place always looks packed, because the service is so fast, they turn the tables over quickly so you're sure to get in and out pretty fast.
This is an oasis of fine diner in the the upper east side of NY. Great food, great service, clean and reasonable prices. You can't beat the Amity

Diner , I will say it again Diner.I have no idea what I have expected but upper east and great reviews in Yelp ...it was not good.The service is good It's fast But seriously , the good is below below average (specially for NY).Have no idea how the reviews in Yelp is so good ...Did I fail on the expectations section ?!

Go to Le Pain across the street.Over priced, below average food, rude waiters. Oh yeah, and the bathroom was disgusting$3 extra for lettuce and tomatoes on your hamburger; $2 extra for avocado on your sandwich for one slice

Worst veggie burger I've ever had. Basic fries. A little over priced. I gave it two stars because it was a cute place with a small diner deal with very nice staff, but the food just wasn't good. The location is a short walk to the MET. Not horrible, but not for me.
Get service, older restaurant though. The waiter was awesome and the food was good. Nice big portions

Looking for a place to eat before going to the Guggenheim and this place is close (by NY standards - 10 minute walk). The service is great to the point where I was surprised that I had to ask for a coffee refill. Fast and friendly. The menu is pretty standard diner with enough options for just about everyone, I think, unless you're looking for something fancy.The coffee was OK - strong and they serve real half and half. I had French toast with bacon and my husband had a Belgian waffle, also with bacon. My French toast was good, not great. The syrup is basic institutional, ok, not great. The bacon was lean and substantial (not super thick, but not thin either), but a few slices were overcooked to the point of being almost burnt. Not bad enough to send it back, but that, combined with cold butter for a Belgian waffle (it just doesn't melt) and just standard fare makes it a solid 3 stars. Prices are good for Museum Mile, I guess. With our two breakfasts, a coke and a cup of coffee, the bill was $35. The bacon took the meals up $4 each, but they brought 4 slices. For this area of town, we would definitely go back to this $$ solid three stars vs. trying some of the $$$ fancy places with limited menus. We're pretty basic people.

Classic diner/deli dining on the upper east side...I like it! Thanks Yelpers for helping find this hidden gem. Dropped in for brunch/lunch after a morning at the Met...I believe they serve breakfast all day so I ordered a broccoli and cheddar omelet.  Dishes other than breakfast are a bit more pricy, but expected due to the location. Service was quick and we got our food soon after ordering...no muss no fuss! The decor is what I expected...it looks like it has not changed since it opened decades ago. The bathroom is tiny so be prepared.

So the other day, I went to go for a quick bite with a buddy of mine. I wanted a good gyro because who the hell DOESN'T want a good gyro? Well, when I got there and ordered my gyro, it looked like an ABOMINATION from hell! Instead of yogurt, they put mayonnaise and instead of good old shawarma, it was BREAKFAST SAUSAGE. So after that, my buddy and I quickly left in disgust, but only after we came home, we realized that I lost my blue hat! I called the restaurant up and asked the staff whether or not they have seen my blue hat. The person answering the phone was extremely rude and said that they had the hat but who ever takes it, takes it. What the heck? I was a paying customer and they treated me like DIRT. I bet you those guys are sniffing my blue hat in the backroom as we speak. So gross, NEVER coming back again.

Abrasive service - seated at a 2 person table in the middle of the floor - interrupted literally 7 times within 10 mins for order....it was honestly the most bizarre experience, particularly given the $$ for a simple diner meal.would not return..

We come here every Saturday morning because the service is excellent. There isn't a better staff in any other diner. It is a pleasure to be a customer.The food is good as well, exactly what you want from a diner.
Don't go! Horrible experience! Extremely rude waiter foisted extra order and wrote his own tip.

Just a fabulous experience in American and some European comfort food. Classic extensive diner menu. Had a Philly cheesesteak wrap and avocado stuffed with chicken salad. Very tasty. The fries - meh. But what makes this such a great lunch experience is the staff and other diners. Greeted warmly by Host, escorted to tiny table and introduced to 5 of the nicest, most endearing waitstaff you could ever meet. Charming, genuinely interested in our comfort, satisfaction with our menu choices. Everyone was someone you whose company you enjoyed. The exact Opposite of the professional crabs that other restaurants train to make you feel small.No one is ever more than a couple of feet from the other diners. No loud voices. Normal conversations at normal volumes. Didn't hear one voice raised to be heard. And the place was packed. Go there. Eat hearty and enjoy a pleasant lunch in the city.

This is a very average diner in my opinion.  It is very cramped and a throwback to the days that these diners were on most blocks in Manhattan.  My scrambled eggs were about as overdone as you can get, as well as the bacon.  However, the staff was very friendly as this is obviously a local hangout.   Still, would I come back?  Absolutely!  I need to try the burgers.  I sense a caring by the ownership of this place that goes a long way for customer satisfaction!

This is the kind of diner that time sadly forgot. It's a friendly place with great casual food in an old school environment. The staff seemed to know half the patrons on a first-name basis, and it was obvious New Amity was an institution in the neighborhood.  One drawback is that New Amity is tiny and tight, and our party of four had to squeeze into a booth, but the employees had a sense of humor about their cozy diner.  Our food was all quite good, although it's a little on the pricey side (as one might expect on the Upper East Side.) This is what casual eating was before the advent of McDonald's and Applebee's: Delicious, friendly and charming.
A great low-frills option with something for everyone. A good family-friendly option just a few blocks from the Met.
Food was good and service was great! Found it by walking down the street and stopping in. Glad we found a good place to eat a quick lunch while near the MET.
Waiter was very attentive. Food was good. Cute little place.  Large selection on menu to choose from.
My friend had a dead fly in her wrap and when we told the waiter he walked away. When I told someone else about the fly they took her wrap off the bill.

This gem of a diner is very close to the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Get the corned beef hash & be in heaven! There are some regulars, but all are welcomed warmly.It's cozy, quick & Greek-owned. What more could you want?After ordering & waiting for less than 7 minutes, our server delivered our food & apologized it took so long. Really? We can wait!Breakfast is served all day & the coffee keeps coming. Next time I'll try the moussaka.
Good restaurant with high quality foods, the servers here are enthusiastic and warm hearted. Only thing need to improve is the room, it would be wonderful if the owner can put more table in it.

Went here after my visit to the Met.It is a typical diner, although the design is really outstanding- they have a really beautiful marine 3-D pano.The service was very welcoming and obsequious. We never had to call our water or wait for anything. The food came fast and hot.The food could have been better- it lacked flavor.It is tho, a nice place to go with your friends after a museum visit and just enjoy big portions for small price ( although their salads are definitely overpriced!)

Unbelievable, they wrote the tips for their customer just because I am Asian! And the fries really like bull shit. If a restaurant has racial discrimination, will never worth me to go their. the worst service I ever met.
Great service, great menu (so many choices) and you would never expect this place in upper east side. Delicious Greek comfort food!

Well, last year i went to this restaurant with my high school classmate after we visited the Met during Halloween. The chicken that they recommended to me was not that delicious, at least we were not that used to the taste...

The bottom line: the fastest service I have ever seen from the friendliest waitstaff I have ever seen in an area where all you see is pretentious eateries.  Hit up Amity for lunch if you're hungry and want to be satisfied in a jiffy.  It's more expensive than diners in Queens, but reasonable given competing prices in the area, especially for lunch.We were looking for a place to grab a quick bite in between appointments and this place bailed us out.  We quickly decided on a chicken salad wrap with fries and then later on ordered some melon with cottage cheese (yeah, I'm trying to lose weight).  I have to tell you, after we ordered I looked up for a moment to utter a word and the next thing I knew the food was in front of me before I could even speak (plus sides of cole slaw and pickle).  Even in light of the discovery of the Higgs Boson, physicists still lack the fundamental knowledge required to explain this phenomenon of ultra fast chicken salad wrap delivery.  What's more is that the food actually tasted good.  What more do you want from a quick lunch in the city?A lot of people complain about the price and it is somewhat pricy.  However, as with all diners, I think the trick is to realize that you don't go to a diner to order Fra Diavolo.  You go to a diner to order breakfast food, appetizers, hamburgers or sandwiches, greek specialties, and dessert.  All of those categories of food there are reasonably priced especially considering that the diner is in the Upper East Side.In any case, give this place a try if you'd like to grab something quick and you want it to be good.

Had the steak it was horrid. Everyone else at the table loves their food tho. I didn't like any party of the steak meal. I did however love the banana spilt! Prices where ok. Could use a remodel.But the staff I tell you are the sweetest people you will ever meet.

Came here after visiting the Metropolitan art museum. Nice and cool inside and has a old timey dinner feel. Quick and friendly service. Our food came within 5 mins of ordering and tasted great. My burger was a little bloody but other than that everything was good.

It's probably one of the cheapest breakfast you can get in this area. They give you a huge portion. Just keep in mind it's a diner, by no means is it anything close to a 5 star restaurant, but the food is ok and fast. It's basically a place to get a quick bite. They serve lunch and dinner, not sure if it's any good. I did notice there were lots of locals in this restaurant.

I loved this place. I was walking on Madison and saw a Gyro picture outside of the restaurant. I ordered the Gyro and it was simply AMAZING! The service was great, the food was great, they are fast and delicious. I recommend!

Overpriced and doesn't have any specialty. Had the Greek salad, vodka pasta, chicken, shrimp pasta, and NY steak. Pasta were blend and steak was overcooked. Average $25 per person. Service was good and attentive though.

A very average dining experience (heavy emphasis on "average"), served with a generous side of disappointment. This diner is conveniently located near my workplace and I decided to go for a late lunch one day. Upon entering, I was greeted by a kitschy interior; the walls are painted with tacky nautical scenes. I sat at one of the booths on the left and found the table fixated uncomfortably close to the bench. I ordered the chicken Caesar wrap, which was essentially a Caesar salad wrapped in a tortilla (not that I was expecting anything more). The menu stated that the wrap comes with sides of fries, pickles, and coleslaw, but it came only with the fries. I asked the waiter about the latter two sides, and in a rude tone he replied, "Oh, you want pickles and coleslaw? Okay, I'll get them for you," as though he was doing me a huge favor. Not only was the meal very average, but service, or perhaps lack thereof, also went downhill throughout my meal. To top it all off, the meal was pricey given the mediocre quality.I will not be returning.

A classic New York Greek diner.  They're going the way of the dinosaur, folks. Enjoy it while it lasts.  I feel sad for the next generation, who won't know the joys of getting a 2-pound, 12-page plasticized menu with 45 selections in each category and the requisite "Greek Specialties" section. Turkey club with French fries. Mmmmmm.
If you want to have your hat stolen don't pass this place up. You'll be even happier if you like sausage and mayonnaise on your gyros. Great job Ernesto.

I used to work right next door so this was my regular stop before work to grab a quick coffee and bagel. Excellent service and I was always greeted my the owner, his wife and the servers. It wasn't long before they all knew my order as soon as I walked in! Great neighborhood diner and very friendly service!

For a UES arena, this place is definitely a humble establishment and refreshing change of pace. My boyfriend and I needed to grab something quick to eat and decided to pop in because the prices seemed slightly cheaper than the diner down the block as UES prices can be painful. We ordered a chicken salad wrap with fries to share. The food was fast, fresh, and the service was most friendly. I really liked how the waiters knew the names of several patrons and the staff was readily available to serve you. If I'm in the area again, I'll definitely stop by!
everything not worth it's price. The toasts were a little bit burned and the omelette was just cooked like an egg pan cake. The only one star is for the waiter's good service.

We were looking for a diner and this place was perfect. We all had true "diner" good -- eggs and corned beef hash and a BLT. It was just what we wanted and we thoroughly enjoyed it. Service was great, super quick and friendly.

Very friendly staff! Had a huge selection of food options and breakfast all day! Food came fast and had welcoming atmosphere. I was impressed with how many people were greeted by name and said hi to the other patrons who were their friends. Felt like I was part of a restaurant family!
This is a real NYC diner.. I've been eating here from 2 years .. food is always consistent and staff amazing.
Awesome neighborhood diner. Friendly staff. Good portions. Charming space. Our favorite ues Simple lunch place

Saw the reviews and this place was worth a stop in after a visit to the Guggenheim. Lots of selections from apps to entrees. We ended up with a Caesar salad and a grilled chicken wrap. Split two ways and was more than enough for mid afternoon. $33 for lunch was a good value the service was fast and the meals were tasty and fresh.

I stopped by here for lunch after an exhausting morning at the Met.  At first site, I almost turned around to look for something else, but decided to stay given the Yelp! Reviews.  Glad I did!It's pretty old school, but the service was top notch and the cheeseburger was excellent.  Quick service and a welcoming atmosphere, what more could you ask for?They have a counter, so it's a good choice if you are solo.  Yelp! always asks if someplace is good for kids, why don't they ask if it's good for someone on their own?
Great diner and great location - near the Met!Average food, reasonable prices, and a super friendly staff.... Only con: tight quarters...

Was in town for work and meeting a friend for breakfast before checking out the Guggenheim. I just wanted a simple breakfast, and found it here. No nonsense place, laminated menu, eggs, toast, breakfast potatoes, sausage, coffee. Great for a relatively inexpensive straight up breakfast on the upper east side. One of my eggs was a tiny bit runny, and the coffee could have been a little better, but on the whole it was just what I was looking for.
Employees are yelling to each other the whole time and is very expensive for such poor quality of food.

This place is great. The menu is big. The prices are reasonable. The service is fabulous. Our food came out in 5 minutes. I ordered a beef gyro. So tasty. Coffee was nice and piping hot.  Friendly owners. It's  located just a short walk from The Metropolitan Art Museum.
Oily food, shady service, hand written bill, mean and racist waitstaff. Never coming back. Aloha!

Came here for lunch on a midweek afternoon because I was at a doctor appointment nearby. I wasn't happy about this place. It's a pretty tired looking with a really expensive menu. $20+ salads on a diner menu? I couldn't believe it. I opted for a turkey wrap and it was the driest thing. I ordered a side salad that had wilted greens (not purposely wilted). Neither tasted good and I didn't finish my food. I wouldn't come back here.
Loved it here.  Ate breakfast before visiting Met.  Everything was perfect.  I got pancakes and sausage.  Wife got an omelette.  The owner chatted with us. Really nice guy.
Great good and fast friendly service! Girlfriend said it was the best Cobb Salad she had ever had. Will definitely go back next time I'm in NYC.

The staff are curtious and friendly and the food is good. If you're taking a break from the Met and you don't want to travel far then the New Amity is a good bet. It is a small diner with limited seating but the staff does their best to turn the tables over quickly. So, don't plan on a lingering lunch if the place is busy. My last visit we each had the turkey club and a corona. The turkey club seemed to have more iceberg lettuce than turkey but it's a small complaint. The lunch came to $50 + tip. Back to the Met!
We were looking for a place to grab a quick bite before going to the Met. Not only was it fresh and delicious, it was served faster than any place I've ever been to.

This is a nice old school diner. The coffee is decent, their breakfast is solid, and the prices are reasonable. Seen people commenting on how expensive it is, I really didn't get that at all. Also it's on Madison, so nice and convenient when heading to or from the park.  Go here when you're hitting a few museums and need a pit stop, or coming back from a day of sunning in Central Park.
Good diner food and a place to sit down after going to the Metropolitan...but you will pay dearly for it.

We walked by to have the owner talk us into coming in for lunch as we read the menu outside. The staff was fast and friendly we had our food hot and it was delicious. I got the gyro sandwich and it was a perfect portion size.  Needless to say we didn't regret being talked into this place!!

SOLID Diner.In the world of pretentiousness that is the Upper East Side, this place is a diamond in the rough.-Staff is attentive.-Place is clean.-Food comes promptly and as ordered.-Owners are friendly.-Prices are comparable to similar places on the UES which means pretty high (but it's all expensive up here)It is heads and shoulders above Nectar on 83rd (Terrible service), E.A.T. ( I would NEVER eat here ever again. See review) & better than Viand (which I don't mind).  All three of these places are closer to me than New Amity and I stil walk the extra two blocks here. It's worth it especially if you are looking for a quick breakfast.  You can be in and out this place with a full stomach  in under 10 minutes if you are so inclined.
The most disgusting meal I had in years. Spaghetti sauce is sour , veal liver burned, eggplant parmigiana bitter and burned. Waiters are ok.
Nice place - good enough coffee shop in NYC (which seem to be dropping like flies).

This little Greek place served up one of the top two burgers I've had while travelling on the west and east coasts. I ordered the American cheeseburger with the "deluxe" option. The meat was juicy and tender, the salad crisp, the bun the non-fancy kind that holds everything together so much better than brioche (I still love a good brioche bun though). I've subtracted a star though because the fries and coleslaw were just average. But the burger, oh, the burger. And the service is excellent, fast and friendly. The setting is a classic old-school, kitschy diner.

3.5 stars (cop out, I know).  Nice quaint diner (though small and often crowded) with that NYC charm, great food, and affable service, but the prices just ruin it for me.I will start out by saying that the food we had was spot on and the service was great.  The turkey on my club was sliced thick (from a real breast even) and my wife's roast beef was ruby red.  Our server was one of those old-school guys who you know has been doing his shtick for decades but doesn't seem tired of it.  One downside, no pickles or coleslaw (you have to choose that or fries) with the sandwiches.  That seems like a diner sin to me.That said, my turkey club was north of $15.  That's edging towards Katz's and 2nd Avenue territory.  For that kind of price, I expect big portions or some other type of distinguishing feature.  Sadly, that was not the case and I would go so far as to say the portion size was a bit on the small size.Normally I don't dock a score for price, assuming that the price is warranted.  I just can't say that that is the case with New Amity.

Service was nice, but quarters were a bit cramped for a party of five.  Our food was OK, but not great.  The only thing that stood out was the Moussaka, but the rest was fine and we weren't starving when we went to the Met afterwards.  I would definitely say the prices were more $$$ than $, though.
Went once past noon.Pretty good eggs. Thought the waiters were rushing us into a fast order and pay so that they could free up the table for the next one.
Went this morning, based on Yelp reviews, before visiting the Met. Food was excellent and VERY fast, every person was incredibly friendly and welcoming. Really old-school atmosphere which I loved.

As advertised. Agree with other reviews. Standard diner for locals mostly. Local charm and fantastic staff. An old school gem that's perfect for your breakfast just before walking around the corner to got to the Met.

I can't believe how lucky I am to have found this place. I first went with an elderly friend of mine and have been returning as often as possible ever since. Solid Greek diner style fare -- breakfast, lunch or dinner...snacks or full courses until you roll out of there. The noise level varies widely with the number of people so if you want it quiet you just have to hit it at the right time. I have no idea when that is, but when I was there from 4:30 to 6:00 PM on a Tuesday evening, it was mellow and I got a bit of work done on my laptop.The wait staff is terrific, the kitchen is fast, consistent and delicious. Friends greet each other on the way to or from their tables; takeout business seems brisk too. What is there not to love?
We loved the friendly and warm service at this Madison Avenue diner. We all had salads and they were huge - we could easily have shared. They were fresh and crisp and tasty.

Great diner-like place on the Upper East Side. The decor is kind of different and you surely feel like you're in your Grandma's house or in the 1950's. Aside from that, nothing to complain about. The service was phenomenal and they were overly attentive. The food was great! I had eggs benedict, banana pancakes, bacon, and home fries. All were absolutely delicious! My coffee was filled up regularly without asking and the prices were very reasonable. I'll definitely be back next time I'm in the city

Hands down, the best restaurant in New York. The food is delivered fast and tastes amazing, what else do you need? Plus, this restaurant gives big portions pretty cheaply which lets you eat like you've never eaten before. 5 stars!

A true, old-school Greek diner just a couple of blocks from the front doors of the Met. Seems impossible until you remember that the headquarters of the Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of America is also just a couple of blocks away. Everything you would expect on the menu of a full-service diner from good omelettes, to homemade chicken soup to moussaka. Ingredients are fresh and food is prepared with care. The coffee is much better than standard diner coffee. The ambiance is cozy, clean and welcoming and the service is prompt and attentive. Nothing fancy, but expect a very solid and satisfying meal that will still leave some drachmas in your pocket.

A pretty standard diner, but nice to find in the upper east side when we were looking for breakfast and didnt want to spend too much money. Food was pretty good, and the staff was friendly.  I'd definitely come back.

This place is definitely a diner, but it's ABOVE where diners are usually. They serve your meals on antique looking floral plates that made me feel like I wasn't at a diner-- and I liked it! The service was excellent, the food was up to expectations and it wasn't very expensive. Try their soups the chicken noodle was awesome! So a soup, omelette and sandwich which ran us about $35 with tip.
Food is delicious here! and my favorite greek waiter is Steve!! Such fast service

Great little spot on the Upper East Side. Good food at a great price. Nice staff and they get your food in a timely manner. Perfect place to go if you need to grab a quick bite; especially if you're going to the Metropolitan Museum if Art and just need to appease your appetite.

Terrible. Went here and had terrible service,with non-authentic food. To top it off I left my hat. Called the diner when i got home, he says "Oh, yes. Hat is here." I say, "Awesome, could you get it for me, i can come pick it up tomorrow." This jerk off has the balls to say, "Well, if someone take it, someone take it, i can't help you boss."So now some Puerto Rican jerk-off pretending to be greek is walking around with my blue beanie. Whatever I had head lice anyways so i hope you guys like head lice in your food, it'd make the bile the serve here better, that's for sure.
Burger mm-mm nasty somewhere between Alpo and hockey puck.

After being very disappointed in the quality of food and the quality of service we received, finding this place was a HAPPY MAKER. Tiny little restaurant, exactly the size I'd expect an Upper East Madison Ave diner to be. The wait staff was awesome, very friendly and you could tell that a lot of people were the "regulars". The food was really good: Eggs over Medium with FOUR pieces of link sausage. Nobody ever gives you four pieces anymore, hash browns done perfectly, freshly squeezed oj, and good buttery toast. Who cares what the food was served on (quaint looking pieces of china), it was done well, quickly, and at a hellofa decent price for the area.

Awesome service, and amazingly delicious food.  Strikes a balance between a throwback casual diner atmosphere with skillfully crafted dishes.  Huge portions.  Can't go wrong here, and so close to the Met.
The service was amazing and they were exceptionally nice to our children. Food was delicious and it's a great location right near the Met.

Cozy diner on Madison Avenue. Feels like it's been there for decades, which I love. Fresh baked goods on the counter, bar area for coffee, and a true diner menu with everything from chicken parm to an egg white and veggie omelet.  Our server was friendly , attentive and didn't make a big deal when I substituted wheat bread for white, mixed veggies for french fries and asked them to go light on the oil. I also tried the chicken noodle soup because it was freezing out and it was VERY good. Having Italian and Spanish grandmothers I consider myself an expert on chicken noodle soup. I would definitely come back here with a group or even alone for a quick bite. There's lots of two-top tables, perfect for dining solo, which is great in New York.

A quick walk from the Met Museum. The staff was friendly and efficient. The food was fresh and delicious.  I had turkey BLT club and my friend had greek chucken wrap. Both were huge, so we had dinner later with the leftovers.  Will visit again.
Easily the best diner in Manhattan. The food is excellent and consistent , the warm and friendly staff is what makes this place a gem. Have an excellent time here !

This is my local diner mainly because 1) there aren't too many other diners around this neighborhood and 2) the food is usually good quality.  I would definitely recommend the veggie burger.  The main downside of eating here is 1) paying $9 for an egg salad sandwich, which should cost 5 and 2) the owners are quite pushy and have no problem shoving you out of your booth the second you finish to get ready for the next guests.  I understand it's NYC restaurant turnover, but if it wasn't my only local diner, I probably would have stopped eating there a long time ago because of the pushy service.  But in terms of quality food, they are fast and it does taste good if you need a break from the Met.
Reasonable prices, nice and homy. Food comes in good quantity and quality. Came back a second time in one day.

a typical greek american diner on 85th st and madison that serves a purpose and  keeps it simple for its patrons.  a small diner compared to other similar diners but space is used to the max and its comfortable with a bunch of couples booths and full booths as well with a long counter with seats if booths are not for you. a typical breakfast, lunch and dinner menu with prices a little higher then the norm, but it is madison ave. the staff are friendly and fast and place is clean and nice and cool inside, the large 3d type painting across the wall is a nice touch with its colors .the seats are comfy and i dont feel rushed even as the place is getting crowded. i did also notice that the decor looks modern and updated but not like most greek diners that are common everywhere.i was here for breakfast and good selection to choose ,eggs, pancakes, french toast, bacon, sausage and more. i will try lunch next time if time permits, some good stuff on menu. i went simple for breakfast and ordered scrambled egg whites with turkey bacon which overall was ok but nothing special, turkey was a little dry. a nice diner with quick friendly service, higher then the norm prices and food which is decent at best. p,s, maybe lunch next time.
This is a lovely bustling diner with excellent service. I really enjoyed the pancakes with bacon and eggs. My favourite pancakes so far in my first trip to US.

Great Place to eat I had a steak and my cousin had a pasta dish.  really good and way cheap.  I am going there again i loved the staff and service.  The owner is a great guy asking if everything is ok more than once.

The place seems to be quite okay, but the food made with very regular standards. If you want have steak, take sirloin, it always good because its just piece of meat, fried in the pan. We also took two wraps, and they were even worse than Twister in KFC. At the end, they tried to charge 10 bucks for the service with a bill of 50. Anyways, no culture, nothing special.

I've only been here for breakfast, but haven't been disapointed. They have pancakes, omlettes and other traditonal breakfast items. But the thing to get here is their fruit topped Belgian waffle. It's not strawberries in gel, it's fresh grapefruit, strawberries, grapes and oranges atop a fluffy delcious waffle. If you are in the area, you should definitely stop in.

We ducked in here on a rainy day because it looked like the least pretentious spot to get lunch while doing a day at the Met. it's an old-school dinner that feels as if it has been there a long time, like a neighborhood landmark.The food was OK but not great...the soup tasted like canned soup, the chicken salad was a little bland. Not bad, but not yummy either. The portions, however, were generous and the food came to our table quickly.The prices for this so-so food were way out of line for the quality. We paid $35 for a lunch for two (my husband got a burger and a cup of soup). The service bordered on rude. The waiter made it obvious he wanted us to hurry up and eat and leave so he could seat another set of people.

A neighborhood gem.  All the servers and staff are friendly, funny and helpful. Food is standard diner fare. Arrive before 1030am on the weekend, and the place is pretty much empty. After that is lively and busy. A lot of locals and a lot of museum tourists.  Food comes out unbelievably fast!

I wish I could give this restaurant 6 stars. My friend Nadia and I went here to get waffle fries. We asked for them crispy and that is exactly what we got. When Nadia asked for BBQ sauce the waiter brought it to us within seconds. They were very quick with everything. I will definitely go back again.
Excellent service and very kind wait staff.  Above average but not amazing food.  Decor could use some work.  Price - dirt cheap.  I'll definitely return.
A lifesaver. Decent enough food, very pleasant and efficient service.  An oasis in the UES desert.

We selected this over the highly rated bakery across the street only because we wanted eggs.  The service was good, however, the food was not up to par with the diner food we hoped to get.  My omelette was overcooked, and the bagel was straight out of the freezer...in NYC...really?  Not bad, but don't go out of your way for it.

This is your old-school neighborhood joint where the old waiters know the old customers and you just order your food and kvetch about stuff with your booth mates and move on.  Basic food, chicken sandwiches, burgers, breakfast, etc.  Good when you need some reliable food, but not a gourmet date spot.
This is a diner that won't let you down any day of the week. I've been going here for a long time, and the service is always great. The food is dependable, and the cheesecake is unparalleled.

Best diner in Manhattan!  A long time favorite of locals who love its friendly waiters, reasonable prices and consistently good food.  After years of leisurely meals I can say that I have never felt rushed by any of the waiters.  Coffee refills are prompt!  Gus, my favorite waiter, always knows what I want before I even get there!
We go out of our way to grab breakfast here on the weekends. Quick, attentive service with above average diner food. A huge selection and enormous portions.

Service was rude.  Seated us at 8:30pm, but didn't let us know that they were going to rush us out (giving us our check at the same time as the food, pulling trash through our aisle of the restaurant for closing, turning of the music and most of staff staring us down to hurry us along).  Additionally, some of food was just bad (dried out baked potato, burnt pita bread) and it took 15 minutes to get a drink after asking 2x...and we were the only 2 customers in the place.  This is a never-go-backer.

It's hard to find a good diner in the Upper East Side. This one is a gem. Cozy booths. Old-school wiaters, older guys mostky, in black pants and white shirts. They are ina  rush. They write nothing down and get the order right every time. Typical sandwiches, anchovies in the Greek saled, nice chocolate egg cream at a reasonable price. Busy but rarely overly crowded.
I've only been here for breakfast and I find it to be mostly mediocre generic American fare.  However, my 90-year-old grandfather loves it.  I guess they make eggs the way he likes them.
Great place that I used to go to all the time in high school.  The last time I was there though the service was a bit rude.  Good overall though.

Good food and good service, but nothing to go out of your way for.  We ended up here when we couldn't find anything else near the Met.  They had typical Greek fare, but we opted for the chicken sandwich.  Prices were high, but so was the quantity of food - one meal was just right for two of us.

Good food, good service, slightly expensive.The thing about this neighborhood is that it is sort of captive - you don't have a lot of choices.  This is a wonderful, family owned diner that has been here forever.  The booths are comfy, the service is speedy but accomodating, and most importantly, the food is savory and the portions are, to me, on the large side.  This is a belly filling joint.  The waiters are like family, the staff tries to accomodate everyone (old people who walk slowly? They'll put you in a booth and take your coat and hang it. Kids in strollers? They'll fold the stroller and store it or if it has to go outside, they watch it.  Big groups? They add tables to the booths and accomodate you.  They'll even move you if you wanted a booth and sat at a table instead.).  The prices are not low and they recently went up, but that's what it takes to pay the rent in this neighborhood.  They will deliver even just a cup of coffee (and frankly, sometimes, I just want a cup of diner coffee). We love this place and eat there and order from there regularly.  This is one of the last old style diners in this area and its a real treasure.

A friend of mine works at the met and took me here for lunch one day. We waited a while for a table, but it was totally worth it! The food was excellent (especially the burgers!) and the staff was very friendly. I will definitely go back there when I'm in the neighborhood.
